Devorah is the coordinator of the group Nuevo Amanecer (New Dawn) 1, 2 & 3, located in the city of Samana, in one of the rural areas surrounded by the water of the Atlantic ocean. Many of the members are selling goods like bread, clothing, shoes or cosmetics. Others sell seafood, run fried food stalls and other businesses.

Devorah lives together with her family, she is still single and has no children. She is starting a nail center with this loan. This is her first loan with us and she will invest it all in supplies for her new nail center. Devorah will buy acrylic nails, accessories, and new gadgets. She said that her most difficult challenge was to get capital to start her business and thanks to the Lord, her neighbors, and Esperanza, this can be possible. 

She is hoping to make her dreams come true: to have a prosperous life and a good business. She thanks all of you for your support!

loans.use: To buy acrylic nails and gadgets

loans.name: Anzhelika

texts.ru: Анжелика торгует мясной продукцией, полуфабрикатами, замороженной продукцией из мяса, фарш, котлеты, окорочка. Очень порядочный клиент, никогда не было опозданий по выплатам, пунктуальная, вежливая, всегда на рабочем месте, всегда можно видеть новый, свежий товар, и большой ассортимент. В этот раз кредит понадобился для закупки замороженной курятины, а также мясного фарша.
texts.en: Anzhelika sells meat products, partially-prepared convenience meals, frozen meat, stuffing, chops, chicken legs.   She is a very honest client, who has never been late with any of her repayments.  She is also punctual, polite, and always at work.  She always has new and fresh merchandise, and a wide assortment of goods.  She has requested this loan to buy frozen chicken and ground beef.

loans.use: to buy frozen chicken and ground meat.

loans.name: Kezian

texts.en:
Kezian lives in Mombasa, Kenya.  She is married and has one child.  She owns an electronics shop that she has been operating for six years now.  She also sells hardware products like padlocks.  Kezian learned about Milango through a friend who invited her to the group.  She joined with the aim of accessing credit in order to improve her business operations.  Her main challenge is the occasional low demand.  

Kezian is applying for a loan of 104,750 Kenyan Shillings to buy electronic gadgets to expand her shop.  Her extra income will be added to her savings to improve her family’s standard of living.  She aspires to expand and to own a larger electronics repair shop where she will sell electronics.

loans.use: to buy electronic gadgets such as fuses, switches, bulbs, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fruits, including mangoes, apples, avocados, and bananas.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy items for his tailor shop including material and needles.

loans.name: Maher

texts.en: Maher is a 29-year-old married man who lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He is a taxi driver, which has been profitable and is the only source of income for his family. Despite his business success, he needs more support to cover costs. He is requesting a youth loan of 100,000 YER from AMB to help him cover the costs of changing the wheels of the taxi he drives. This will improve the taxi's condition and increase the business' profit.

loans.use: to buy wheels for his taxi for transportation.

loans.name: Vamba

texts.en: Vamba, 32, is very hard-working and focused on his business. He has had this business for the past eight years. He is married with two children who are between the ages of 9 and 12 and are currently in school. Vamba and his family resides in New Kru. He sells bread, soft drinks, hand cream, toothpaste, sardines, biscuits, candy, gin and many other items. He has many customers and makes a profit; his provision shop is the only shop in the community. He started with a little amount (LRD25,000) that he had been saving from the sale of scratch cards. He is requesting a loan to purchase more sardines, biscuits, soft drinks, toothpaste and hand cream to improve his business. He hopes to give his children a higher level of education.

loans.use: to purchase more sardines, biscuits, soft drinks, toothpaste, and hand cream to improve the business.

loans.name: Kazungu

texts.en:
Kazungu lives in the Likoni area of Coast Province, Kenya.  He is a married father of five school going children.  Kazungu is a clothes dealer, a trade which he has been operating for eight years.  He also plans to set up a retail shop and is applying for a loan of 5,450 KES to buy more retail products for the shop (sugar, flour, etc).  

He learned about Milango through a friend and joined with an aim of accessing credit to improve business operations.  The challenge he is facing is the presence of second-hand clothes in the market, which reduces the demand for new and readymade clothes.  The extra income from the loan will be added to his savings to improve his family’s standard of living.  His plans for the future are to increase the operations of the retail shop.

loans.use: to buy more retail products including sugar, flour, etc.

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen is a resident of Mariakani area of Coast province, Kenya. She is married and has two children. Maureen owns a retail shop where she sells charcoal--a business that she has been running for two years. She also has a hairdressing business and sells water. She received the start-up capital from her husband.

She learned about Milango from other clients and joined the institution with an aim of accessing credit to improve the operations of her business. Her main challenge is the high cost of stock and competition.  

Maureen is applying for a loan of 21,050 Kenya shillings to purchase flour, cooking oil, sugar and a blow drier for the hairdressing shop. The extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve her living standard. She aspires to own other shops and pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking oil, sugar and a a blow drier for the hairdressing shop.

loans.name: Gertrude J.'s Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers from one of the vocational institutes in Makama village, an outskirt of Makeni city. This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL15,400,000 for the entire group in order to meet their immediate financial needs. At the end of each month, they will repay the loan using their monthly salaries. Their school’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT/Kiva lenders on their behalf.

Daniel is the featured leader of this group of teachers. Daniel, 42, is a native of Makeni. He is married and has four children. His wife is a teacher and his children attend primary and secondary schools. Daniel has been a school teacher for 14 years now. Daniel wants to pursue further studies in college. He has requested this loan in order to pay his college fees.

loans.use: to pay his college fees.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is 43 years old, married, and has four children, two of whom are in school.

Imelda is in the agricultural business: she buys and sells livestock in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional livestock to raise.

Imelda has been buying and selling livestock for 9 years now and has borrowed 16 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Imelda would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional livestock to raise.

loans.name: Kevin

texts.en:
Kevin is a resident of Kongowea, Kenya. He is a married father of two school-going children and has a salon business. He has run this business for the last year. He is also formally employed. He desires to set up a barber shop.

He learned of Milango from a friend and joined in order to access funds. He is applying for a loan of 41,900 Kenya shillings to buy cosmetics, lotions, hair bands, etc.

The only challenge in the business is lack of capital for expansion, a problem he sees partly sorted by this loan. Kevin is determined to carry out his operations well because he believes that it is from such a venture that he can establish a good life for his family. His future ambition is to be able to set up other locations.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, lotions, hair bands, etc

loans.name: Ariuntsetseg

texts.en: Mrs. Ariuntsetseg is 43 years old and lives with her husband and son in a ger in the Niseh district of Mongolia. Her husband Batbold, 42, is unemployed. Her son, Nyamdorj, who is 15, is a freshman at university. Mrs. Ariuntsetseg works at a private oil company in a gas station. She used to work at a pig farm for years. She is planning to start her own pig farm due to her experience. She has just bought two pigs and three baby pigs and now she is requesting 1,000,000MNT to build a barn for the pig farm. She is a diligent and hard-working person.

loans.use: to build a barn for a pig farm.

loans.name: Sherly

texts.en: Sherly is a new member of PMPC under the micro-finance program. She is 36 years old and married with three school-aged children. She operates her food products business in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns an average monthly income of Php 2,000. She has requested a loan from PMPC in the amount of Php 5,000 to purchase additional ingredients for food processing. She plans to increase her production and sales and to invest more capital in the business so she can save for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for food processing.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth. She is 27 and a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jose, a driver, and is a mother. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Elizabeth is an egg retailer. She buys eggs from wholesalers and sells them at a small profit. Customers are attracted due to the low selling prices she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

Elizabeth is requesting a loan amounting to PhP10, 000 that she will use in purchasing additional eggs. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Elizabeth hopes her business will continue to grow so they may be able to have their own house and lot. She dreams to give her children a good and quality education all by the grace of God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional eggs needed for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his mobile money transfer working capital

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 48 years old, married, and has five children. She has been farming rice in the Philippines for 22 years, and earns additional income from food vending. 

Jocelyn is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies for her rice crop.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business and secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Maa Santoshi Atma Mahila Group

texts.en:
Subani is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Subani was born in the Khurda district of Odisha, India 48 years ago. The lady wearing a yellow and white colored sari standing second from the left in the photo is Subani. She is married and the couple has one child who is attending school.

For five years now, Subani has been selling rice, cooking oil, lentils, spices, onions, packaged food items like biscuits, cake etc. in her grocery shop.

Subani, along with her group members, has applied for a loan of 220,000 INR. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

Subani will use her share of the loan to expand her business. She will buy biscuits, chocolate, lentils, rice, wafers, detergent, salt, pepper, shampoo, toothbrushes, tooth paste, etc. at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to purchase biscuits, chocolate, lentils, rice, wafers, detergent, salt, pepper, shampoo, toothbrushes, tooth paste etc. for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Minati

texts.en:
Minati is a 43-year-old divorced lady living with her brother and sister-in-law. She owns and manages a dairy farm where she has one cow. She sells eight liters of milk per day and earns 3,000 INR per month. Her monthly income is not enough for her family. After she got divorced from her husband, she came back to her brother's house. She does not want to be a burden on him so she started selling milk in her village.
.
She wants to purchase two Jersey cows for her farm as the demand for cow’s milk has increased in the village. She also has a plan to repair the shed for her cattle and enlarge it. 
.
She has requested a loan of 25,000 INR to purchase two cows and renovate the shed. In the future, she wants to enlarge her farm and sell more milk products like yogurt, butter etc.

She has a dream of giving a quality life to her family and saving some money for her future.

loans.use: to purchase two cows for her dairy business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
A married parent of three children, Josephine works hard to support her family.

She has a greengrocer business in the Philippines. She earns additional income by carrying on a food eatery business and a general store, and by raising pigs. Josephine is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF.  She will use the loan to buy fruits and vegetables to resell in her greengrocer business.

Josephine has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream -- to save enough money so that she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to resell

loans.name: Balaram

texts.en:
Balaram is a 45-year-old physically challenged person living with his wife and four children. His son is working in a company and his three daughters are studying at college. Balaram works as a driver at a travel agency, where he gets daily wages. He is not able to look after his family properly and fulfill their demands.

Balaram has an idea to purchase a second-hand auto rickshaw so that all the income comes to his pocket instead of only the labor cost. He says that doing so will improve his monthly income and his family's economic condition.

He has applied for a loan of 50,000 INR to purchase a second-hand auto rickshaw. He will use the auto rickshaw to carry passengers from one place to another.

He has a dream of having his daughters well educated and saving some money for their marriage.

loans.use: to puchase an auto rickshaw.

loans.name: Alita

texts.en:
Alita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell like soft drinks, bread, candies, canned goods, eggs, etc. for her general store business.

Alita has been in this business for 15 years. She earns more income from farming sugarcane.

Alita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell like soft drinks, bread, candies, canned goods, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga is 48 years old and married with four children.

Dominga works hard to provide for her family. She runs a charcoal-selling business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Dominga has borrowed and repaid 23 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the charcoal business for 3 years and also earns income from raising pigs and vegetables.

Dominga aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Alba Nelis

texts.es:
Alba, realiza la venta de pupusas y bebidas refrescantes, se decidió por un nuevo préstamo, para la temporada de los meses próximos, comprara una parte de bebidas, quesillo, aceite, chicharrón, y otros materiales para hacer pupusas, tambien comprara pólvora para la época.
Con el préstamo anterior ayudo a mejorar en el fortalecimiento de su negocio, actualmente tiene diversificado su negocio, vende pan, vende comida los domingos, sale a las ferias tambien a ofrecer mercadería.
texts.en:
Alba has a business selling pupusas (a traditional dish made with thick corn tortillas) and soft drinks.  She has decided to request a new loan so that she can buy drinks, cheese, cooking oil, pork, and other supplies to make pupusas over the next few months.  She will also buy fireworks for the holiday season.

Her previous loan helped her to strengthen her business so that she now has a more diversified business.  She sells bread, food on Sundays, and she also goes out to the markets to offer her products for sale.

loans.use: to buy drinks, cheese, cooking oil, pork and fireworks

loans.name: Adikanda

texts.en:
Mr. Adikanda, 36 years old, is a physically challenged person living with his small family in Odisha, India. His family consists of his mother, his son who is five years old and his wife. His mother is a housewife.  He is the only person in his family earning a living and three members are depending on his income. 

He started a general store in his village nine years ago. His village consists of 100 families and there are three shops. People are dependent on these three shops for grocery items and snacks. So he started a general store selling food items like rice, cooking oil, and packaged food items like biscuits, cake etc.   But due to lack of funds, he cannot meet the growing demands of the customers so he needs the financial support for his growth.

He has requested a loan of 20,000 INR to purchase food items in bulk and repair his shop so that he can meet the market demand.

loans.use: to purchase food items like rice, cooking oil, and packaged food items like biscuits, cake etc. for his general store

loans.name: Prakash Chandra

texts.en:
Prakash Chandra is a 29-year-old differently able person living with his parents and younger brother who is 27 years old and also a differently able person. Prakash Chandra owns and manages a grocery shop where he sells betel, spices, shampoo, detergents, oil, incense sticks, wafers, biscuits, soap etc. He has a monopoly in the village because there is no other grocery shop in the village and all the people are dependent on his shop. As there is more demand for his products in the village, he has to go to the market to purchase the products very frequently.

Prakash Chandra has a plan to purchase the goods in bulk to meet the customers' demands and to reduce his transportation cost by not making frequent visits to the market. He says that this will help him increase his monthly income.

He has requested a loan of 20,000 INR to purchase stock in bulk for his grocery shop. He wants to provide his family with the basic necessities of living and save some money for his future.

loans.use: to purchase betel, spices, shampoo, detergents, oil, incense sticks, wafers, biscuits, soap etc. in bulk for his grocery shop.

loans.name: Banita

texts.en:
Banita is a 33-year-old lady living with her mother and child. She manages a tailoring shop where she sews dresses like salwars (traditional Indian dress) etc. for her customers who give orders for sewing. After her husband left her, she was burdened with her child's responsibilities so she started a tailoring shop. She earns only 5,000 INR per month from this business.

She has planned to purchase two new sewing machines so that she can enlarge her business and take orders from her customers in bulk. She has requested a loan of 20,000 INR to purchase two sewing machines and fabrics. She also wants to hire some workers to help her. 
 
She wants her child to study in a good school and save some money for her family's future.

loans.use: to purchase two sewing machine and fabrics for her tailoring shop.

loans.name: Badamtsetseg

texts.en:
Badamtsetseg is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ger in Hentii province of Mongolia. Her husband, Damdinpurev, provides transportation services between the capital city and Hentii province. Her son, Hishigjargal, and daughter, Anuhatan, ages 10 and 11 years old, go to secondary school, while her youngest daughter, Tselmuun, age 3,  goes to kindergarten. 

Badamtsetseg has been working as saleswoman since 2007, and has built strong relationships with her customers and suppliers. She is now planning to open her own clothing retail business in the local market and she is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to purchase starting inventory for her new business. She is a positive and diligent person.

loans.use: to purchase starting inventory for her new clothing retail business.

loans.name: Julinda

texts.en:
Julinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a ready-to-wear clothing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy additional stocks of clothing to sell at her ready-to-wear clothing business.

Julinda has been in this business for 20 years. She earns additional income from raising pigs and buying and selling livestock.

Julinda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of clothing to resell.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is 62 years old and lives in Talic, Oroquieta City. She is married with 3 children. She has a shop where she sells automotive lubricant/oil and earns approximately PHP 10,000.00 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan to purchase materials for her shop.
 
Nelly has been a member of PMPC for 11 years. In the future, Nelly hopes to have more savings.

loans.use: to purchase materials for her automotive lubricant/oil business.

loans.name: Batrentsen

texts.en:
Batrentsen is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a small house in Arhangai province of Mongolia. His wife, Olzii-Utas, age 30, works at a clothing retail counter in the local market. His two daughters, Haliun and Lhagvadulam, ages 8 and 3, go to primary school and kindergarten. 

Batrentsen has been helping his wife to run the clothing retail business since 2004. Now he is planning to provide transportation services to local customers and is requesting 4,000,000 MNT to fix and renovate his old car in order to run his newly started business. He is a friendly, communicative and hardworking person.

loans.use: to fix and renovate his old car in order to run his newly started business of providing transportation services.

loans.name: Emilda

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Emilda works hard to support her family.

She has a business selling charcoal in the Philippines and also earns additional income from coffee vending, raising pigs, and rice retailing. Emilda is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Emilda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 66 years old and married with four children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Erlinda is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Erlinda has been raising pigs for 20 years and also earns additional income from her general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita, 54, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Moises, a carpenter and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Teresita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her inventory. 

Teresita hopes to help her grandchildren finish college and dreams that her business will continue to grow. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is married with five children. She is 52 years old and lives in Calube, Aloran Misamis Occidental.

Elsa runs a general store and sells rice to earn a living. She has had this business for 5 years. Each month, she earns PHP 2,500 doing this type of work.  She has requested a loan of PHP 14,900 to purchase more stock for her general store such as toothpaste, soap, shampoo, etc.

In the future, Elsa hope to buy new galvanized metal sheeting.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store such as toothpaste, soap, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy  is 42 years old and lives in Dullan, Aloran Misamis Occidental. She is married with five children.
 
Juvy  works in a "carinderia" (local eatery) for a living. She has requested a loan to repair her house. In the future, Juvy hopes to have more savings.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa is 47 years old and lives in Mialem, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with six children.
 
Felisa has a store and sells groceries and other consumable products. She is also engaged in corn production activities and earns approximately PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing groceries and other consumable products for her existing business.

Felisa has been a member of PMPC for four years. In the future, Felisa hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to be used in purchasing groceries and other consumable products.

loans.name: Asmaa

texts.en:
Asmaa, who appears in the picture, is a 28-year-old young woman.  She is married and a mother to one son. Her husband is a worker with a low salary. In addition to his income, they have also been raising sheep, selling the sheep and sheep products.

Asmaa is studying at the university, specializing in teaching methods. Asmaa wants to complete her studies, but first she must pay the university fees so she is requesting a USD 1000 loan from FATEN to help cover her fees. This will ensure a better future for Asmaa and improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: To pay university fees.

loans.name: Sibaprasad

texts.en:
Sibaprasad is a 44-year-old differently able person living with his parents and his brother. He is the only one earning an income in his family. He has a variety shop in his home. He has 20 years of experience in this field. He earns 10,000 INR in a month by selling packaged food items like biscuits, chocolate, spices, betel, soap, detergent, noodles, oil, pickles, sauces, rice etc.  This is not sufficient for him to manage his family. To grow his business, he wants some financial support. 

He has applied for a loan of 50,000 INR to purchase more stock of what he sells. He hopes to build a house for his parents and save some money for his future.

loans.use: to purchase biscuits, chocolate, spices, betel, soap, detergent, noodles, oil, pickles, sauses, rice etc for his variety shop.

loans.name: Luis

texts.es: Luis  tiene 70 años y desde hace más de 35 años se dedica a producir café. Junto con sus 6 hijos han hecho de esta actividad un negocio familiar alternando con esto la cría de conejos que le deja una ganancia extra  que los ayudado a salir adelante. Anteriormente el café que producían era convencional sin embargo con el paso del tiempo han logrado convertir esta producción en su totalidad a café orgánico, es decir que ya no utilizan fertilizantes con productos químicos en sus fincas. Durante la última cosecha tuvieron una producción de 5 toneladas y para esta tienen planeado llegar a 8 toneladas ya que anteriormente sembraron nuevas plantas las cuales ya comenzaran a dar frutos. Luis  necesita de un crédito porque va a realizar labores de limpieza y abono en sus fincas para poder llegar a la meta que se ha propuesto. También va a renovar una parte de su parcela para que dentro de 3 años su producción sea aún mayor y también pueda seguir manteniendo el nivel de calidad que hasta la fecha ha tenido. Entre las metas personales que Luis tiene esta la de poder ampliar su casa para poder dejarles en el futuro un buen patrimonio a sus hijos y nietos
texts.en:
Luis is 70 years old and for more than 35 years has been producing coffee. Together with his 6 children they made this work into a family business alternating with this the breeding of rabbits which leaves them with extra profit which helps them to get ahead. Previously the coffee that they produced was conventional however with the passage of time they succeeded in converting this production in its entirety into organic coffee. This is to say that they now do not use fertilizers with chemical products in their farms. During the last harvest they had a production of 5 tons and because of this they have planned to arrive at 8 tons since previously they sowed new plants which are already starting to bear fruit.

Luis needs a loan because he is going to do farm work cleaning and fertilizing his farms to be able to arrive at the goal that he proposed. He is also going to renovate part of his plot because within 3 years his production will be even bigger and he will also be able to continue maintaining the quality level that until this date he has had. Among the personal goals that Luis has is to be able to enlarge his house to be able to leave a good inheritance in the future to his children and grandchildren.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizers which will help him to increase his production as well as for the payment of the labor for the weeding and pruning of his farm.

loans.name: Shannon

texts.en:
Entrepreneurship is in Shannon’s blood.  His father worked as a contractor in the transportation industry and his mother was also an entrepreneur for several years. 

Before operating Valet Transportation, a wheelchair and non-emergency transportation business, Shannon compared the necessities and possible risks with his family’s experience. A graduate from The University of Texas at San Antonio, Shannon says, “My father and I felt confident that we would be successful.”

In May 2012, Shannon and his parents began the business, offering reduced rates and “increased quality care.”  He says because they have a small number of clients and one van, he and his family can offer more personalized customer service. 

Valet Transportation doesn’t have a website or social media page but runs completely off word of mouth and direct marketing. “We have an agreement with nursing homes and an emergency transportation business which calls us when they have overflow,” Shannon says. 

A client can pay $200 to $300 for a stretcher van, which is how most emergency vehicles work, since they may not be equipped with wheelchair harnesses or ramps.  His company charges $80 round-trip in an Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) certified van equipped with wheelchair necessities.

Shannon found out about Accion Texas Inc. six years ago during a UTSA seminar about how to generate operating income. “I never deleted that number from my phone,” Shannon says. The loan will repair the van and be used as cash flow. “We bill the nursing homes and they take 30-90 days to get to us,” Shannon says. “Our invoices show we make a monthly profit, but we don’t see it until they pay.”

The loan eased the family’s financial worries and freed them to complete preventive maintenance. Shannon says, “We wouldn’t have been able to obtain more clients without these procedures. We would have had to wait two to three months before making that money ourselves.” 

Valet Transportation also provides services to grocery stores, clinics, pharmacies and any other places their clients need to go. “Our service is a lot cheaper than calling a cab,” Shannon says. “Our clients rely on us instead of other means.” 

Shannon’s goal is to purchase another van and employ two full-time drivers by summer 2013. Without the help of an Accion loan, Shannon would need to wait before extending services, and would have to pay out of pocket for daily operating expenses. 

Shannon says, “I had a good experience with Accion. The rate we got was a lot lower than expected.”

loans.use: to pay for vehicle maintenance.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida is 42 years old and married with five children. She's presently residing at Caticugan, Siquijor, Siquijor.

She has been engaged in this business for two years and earns P 15,000 every month to make a living. She had requested a loan amounting to PHP 10,000 in order to purchase more products.

She has been a member of PMPC for almost two years with good credit records. In the future, she hopes to have business expansion.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials.

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly is 40 years old and married with five children.

Merly works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock such as candies, bread, coffee, biscuits, soft drinks, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store.

Merly has borrowed and repaid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 3 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Merly aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stock such as candies, bread, coffee, biscuits, soft drinks, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store

loans.name: Rowelyn

texts.en:
Rowelyn is 23 years old and has a live-in partner with two kids. They presently reside in Panlautan, Siquijor, Siquijor.

She has had this business for a year and earns a monthly net income of PHP 1,800 for their living expenses. She had requested a loan amount of PHP 5,000 to continue operating her sari-sari (general store) business.

In the future, she hopes to be successful in her business and have business expansion for the benefit of her family.

loans.use: to purchase assorted products for her business.

loans.name: Ronie

texts.en:
Ronie is 26 years old, single and presently residing in Caticugan, Siquijor, Siquijor.

His source of income is from fishing and he earns six thousand pesos (PHP 6,000) every month, which challenged him to have more fishing materials, so he has requested a loan amounting to PHP 3,000.

He has been a member of PMPC for a one and a half years with good credit records.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials.

loans.name: Kamala Group

texts.en:
The name of this Joint Liability Group is Kamala. All four active women entrepreneurs in this group belong to Bhawanipatna town in the Kalahandi district in Odisha, India. Kalahandi district is a very poor region of the country with poverty and underdevelopment. Rashmirani, standing second from the right with a red-colored sari in the photo, is one of the members of this group. She is 26 years of age and lives with her husband, her four-year-old son, father and mother-in-law. 

Rashmirani has been running a fabrication workshop for the last 13 years in a temporary shed with the active participation of her husband, who looks after all activities of the business. She has engaged three skilled workers in her fabrication works @ 3,000 INR each per month. She manufactures grills, shutters, windows, doors and other iron products per the orders of the customers. Her monthly net income from the fabrication work is around 5,000 to 6,000 INR. In her opinion, her present income is insufficient to manage the fabrication as well as household expenses. Her husband purchases iron materials from the local market regularly as needed. 

With the present loan, she is planning to purchase iron rods, angles, and iron sheets in bulk to save the unnecessary expenses incurred due to price fluctuation of the materials and transportation. With this, she will earn some extra income for her family. Rashmirani has a dream of providing a better education for her child and constructing a good workshop for her fabrication unit in the near future. Also, she has a big hope of constructing a house of her own in due course.  
 
The other three members of her group are Gitanjali, Niharika and Kuni who are running a vegetable farm, an electrical shop and a shoe business.

loans.use: To purchase iron rods, angles, and iron sheets

loans.name: Enrique

texts.en:
Seventeen years ago, Enrique began his career as a truck driver. He decided to go into business for himself when he lost his job earlier this year.

He started a towing business with his own truck, but he still needed start-up funds for working capital, liability and cargo insurance, and licensing.

After a friend and client of Accion Texas Inc. told him about his own positive experience, Enrique applied for a loan and was approved.

Now he owns Rocky Mountain Towing, a small business that transports cars for mechanics from streets to body shops, and from shops to auto dealerships.  Enrique works on-call and is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week in his hometown of El Paso, Texas. 

He currently works alone, but plans to hire a crew as soon as he can afford to purchase multiple trucks. Without the help of an Accion loan, Enrique says, “I wouldn’t be able to begin my business.”

loans.use: to cover working capital, liability and cargo insurance, and licensing costs.

loans.name: Ma. Elma

texts.en:
This is Ma. Elma, 53, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Joselito and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Ma. Elma operates a junk shop. Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines, and while waiting for their local dump trucks to collect the garbage, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic, paper and other materials. They sell these to junk shops for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean, and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries like factories and others of the like. Aside from this she also raises pigs in her compound. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be incorporating the loan to buy recyclable materials and to buy scavenged materials from collectors which she will use in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she purchases more materials.  

Ma. Elma hopes to grow her business and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for recyclable materials and to buy scavenged materials from collectors which she will use in her business.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a ready-to-wear clothing retail business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to buy additional stock of clothing to sell.

Milagros has been in this business for 5 years. She earns additional income from selling frozen foods.

Milagros has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en:
Ginalyn is 21 years of age and is married with three children. She presently resides in Caticugan, Siquijor, Siquijor.

She has engaged in the fishing business for almost ten years and earns PHP 5,000 as monthly net income.

She hopes to expand her business in the future, so she has requested a loan amount of PHP 4,000 for her second cycle.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
When Ofelia came to America from Mexico, she dreamed about doing what she loves: She wanted to own a skin care and beauty business. She later joined Mary Kay, a wholesale beauty supply company. She was drawn to it because of the product quality and the 50 percent discount on inventory purchases.  

For three years now, Ofelia has worked as an independent Mary Kay consultant in Metairie, LA. 

In her hometown, Ofelia learned the art of the retail sale by selling gold jewelry, which she often still sells. With the assistance of other Mary Kay consultants, Ofelia learned more about her new products and company.

Ofelia has a team of four consultants. She says the Accion Texas Inc. loan helped her business, especially considering she couldn’t receive the assistance from a traditional bank. “It’s very emotional,” she says. 

Mary Kay offers Ofelia the opportunity to advance professionally. But without the Accion loan, purchasing the inventory needed to make sales would have been much more challenging.

A friend who was a previous Accion client told her about the non-profit microlender, so she applied. The Accion lending team helped her understand the application and underwriting process at every turn and she was approved for a loan. “It was great working with Accion,” she says. 

The loan helps Ofelia make product information sheets and purchase inventory and miscellaneous materials to create appealing prizes for current clients. These items include bags, tissue paper, baskets and small products for current clients. Without an Accion loan, Ofelia says, “I would have been able to purchase the inventory, but it would have been hard.”

To learn more about the Mary Kay products Ofelia offers, visit her website: http://www.marykay.com/oposas/en-US/Pages/default.aspx?lcov=1.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for her skin care and beauty business.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is 44 years old and lives in Dela Paz, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She is married with five children.
 
Maricel has a stall where she sells a variety of fruit. She has had this business for almost three years. She requested a loan to be used for purchasing additional fruit for resale.

Maricel has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fruit for resale.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
This is Ruth, 25, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jonjie, a sales agent, and is a mother. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Ruth operates a piggery. She earns by selling live hogs to meat dealers. Sometimes they have the pigs slaughtered and sold in the market. Aside from this, she also cooks breakfast meals for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1,200 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 15, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy feed and additional hogs. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ruth hopes to give her children a good life and a good education by the grace of God. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and it is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for feed and additional hogs needed for her business.

loans.name: Golngai Group

texts.en:
Golngai group was formed in 2009 and has 10 members. The literal meaning of "Golngai" can be closely translated as “besotted friend”. These tribal women belong to Kholep village of Manipur state, which is in the northeastern part of India. In order to empower themselves and contribute to their family incomes, they mean to help one another to get a loan as a group.

Hevei is pictured with her hand raised. She is 38 years old and a mother to three sons and one daughter. Her husband, Seikhohao, earns money as a wood cutter. With a tight budget, they barely manage their children's schooling. She grows a homestead garden for food. Before she got a loan, she would work doing anything for a day’s wage. There are times when she has to baby-sit and wash clothes to get paid. The nature of her work as a wage earner began to have an adverse effect on the children. Since then, to protect her children's emotions, she got a loan to make a difference in their lives.

With part of her first loan, she bought piglets and yarn to weave. She weaved three shawls in a month. With her second loan, she continued her activities and she was happy that she actually earned more than her previous daily wages. She actually bought a TV using her income, which made her children very proud. She said, “The day I bought the TV, I felt like I was on top of the world. It may sound funny for others but for me and my family it is a great achievement”. Eventually, her activities became the source of the family income. She has contacts and plans to supply the woven shawls and wrap-round at a large scale to retailers of the same products.       

She needs and requested another loan from Kiva to improve upon her weaving activities. She wishes to continue weaving for her main source of income. She plans to utilize the loan to purchase one handloom (a simple machine to weave) and to buy yarn of varied quality to weave. Raising pigs is a long-term profit source, which she conveniently wishes to continue. This can serve as a backup plan for any emergency.

Likewise, the rest of the group members, too, need and requested another loan to do better with their income-generating activities. The group is very happy to know that their loan comes from all around the world. The members pray for God’s blessing for everyone who has lent their money to make a difference in their lives.

loans.use: to purchase one handloom (a simple machine to weave) and buy yarn of varied quality to weave

loans.name: Felecia

texts.en:
Felecia is 62 years old and lives in Misom, Baliangao. She is married with one child. 

To earn a living, Felecia has a business selling grocery items and beverages. She earns about PHP 4,900 each month doing this type of work. Felecia has requested a loan to purchase more stock for her grocery store .

Felecia has been a member of PMPC for four years.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Bazarsad

texts.en:
Bazarsad is 69 years old and lives with her son in a Ger in Har Horum in Dornogovi province of Mongolia. Her son has just graduated from university and plans to open an auto parts retail store. 

Bazarsad has been operating a small general store near her home since 2003. She is well-known in the area and she is now requesting 3,000,000 MNT to purchase auto spare parts for her son's newly started business. Bazarsad is a hardworking and responsible woman who says, "I will help my son to start his own business and mentor him on how to run his business in the area."

loans.use: to purchase auto spare parts for her son's newly started auto parts retail store.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 59 years old and lives in Nacional, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is widowed with one child. 

Monica has a store that sells groceries and other consumable products. She has had this business for almost five years. She requested a loan to be used for purchasing additional groceries for resale.

Monica has been a member of PMPC for almost two years.  In the future, Monica hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries for resale.

loans.name: Gavina

texts.en: Gavina is a a new micro-finance member of PMPC. She is 47 years old and married with four adult-age children and two school-age children. Gavina is engaged in a fish vending business and has operated the business for ten years, with a monthly average income of Php 5,000. She has requested a loan of Php 3,000 to purchase fishing nets. She hopes to have more capital to use in the business and to save for the future.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is married with four children. She is 45 years old and lives in Poblacion, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay.

Marivic sells balut and banana cue to earn a living and has had this business for four years. She has requested a loan for additional capital. Marivic has been a member of PMPC this year 2012. In the future, Marivic hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more eggs to cook as balut, and additional capital for banana cue.

loans.name: Dezelyn

texts.en:
This is Dezelyn, 30, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Allan, an accounting officer, and she is a mother. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Dezelyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Dezelyn hopes to give her children a good quality education and dreams to expand her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and it is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente is 46 years old, married and has four children: one infant and three who are school age. They presently reside in Canlambo, Larena, Siquijor.

Vicente has had a fishing business for more than 15 years and earns PHP 6,000 a month to meet the family's needs. He has requested a loan amount of PHP 5,000 to purchase some fishing net materials.

He has been a member in this institution with good credit records, and he aims to have more fishing nets for a better living.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net materials.

loans.name: Merli

texts.en:
Merli is 54 years old, married with four children, and presently resides in Tacloban,Larena, Siquijor.

She has been engaged in this business for two years and earns PHP 2,000 to make a living. She had requested a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 for purchasing feed for her hog raising business.

In the future, she hopes to be successful in this kind of activity and to use her income for more savings.

loans.use: to purchase more feed for her hogs.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is 44 years old and married with seven children.

She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Merlinda is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional livestock to raise.

Merlinda has been raising livestock for ten years and also earns additional income from food vending and a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock to raise.

loans.name: Saroen's Group

texts.en:
Saroen resides in a rural area of the Battambang Province’s Bovel district, Cambodia. She is 43 years old and married with four children, three of whom are dependent on her and still in school. To support her family, she has been involved in raising pigs for ten years. The current business earns her family around 20,000 KHR per day and allows her to save about 10,000 KHR every day for future needs. 

Saroen’s group consists of two members who have been with VisionFund for three cycles and completely paid back the loans. Saroen has wisely used the loans to better support her family with enough food, as well as supporting her children’s education. Now she is leading her group to seek for a loan. Saroen will use her portion to buy materials for construction of a sanitary bathroom (such as a toilet), tile drainage, and sewage. She hopes this loan will enable her family to have a sanitary bathroom to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy materials for construction of a sanitary bathroom.

loans.name: Lay's Group

texts.en:
Lay, 34 years old, is a married mother of six children, all of whom are dependent on her and still in school. To make a living, she has been in rice farming for several years. Her husband works as a solder in the local area. Lay is able to earn about 17,000 KHR per day and manages to save about 8,000 KHR each day after paying for daily expenses. 

Lay’s group consists of three members who live in the same village in the Battambang province’s Bovel district of Cambodia and she is a third-time borrower with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Lay and her group members are applying for a loan of 200,000 KHR each. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy materials for constructing a proper latrine, including toilet bowls, tile drainage etc. She hopes this loan will enable her to have a clean latrine for her family to use.

loans.use: To buy materials to construct a proper latrine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Marcosa

texts.en:
Marcosa is 60 years old and lives in Dapacan Bajo, Calamba. She is married with 10 children. 

Marcosa has a business that sells dried fish. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan to purchase 10 boxes of dried fish to sell.

Marcosa has been a member of PMPC for five years.

loans.use: To purchase dried fish to sell

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Mylene works hard to support her family.

She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines and earns additional income from food vending, raising livestock and running a general store. Mylene is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle transport business.

Mylene has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts to maintain her motorcycle

loans.name: Javzmaa

texts.en:
Javzmaa, 21 years old, lives with her parents and sister in a small house in the Bulgan province of Mongolia. Her father is a security guard at the Social Insurance Department and her mother Narangerel is chef at government agency. Her sister Urtnasan is a senior university student. 

Javzmaa has been working part-time in a local market as a saleswoman since she was a student. She has gained experience of how to manage a clothing retail business. Now she is planning to operate a clothing retail business herself in a local market. She is requesting 1,135,000 MNT to purchase starting inventory for her business. She is a responsible, diligent and honest person.

loans.use: to purchase starting inventory for her new clothing retail business

loans.name: Nilo

texts.en:
Nilo is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an electronic re-loading business in the Philippines. 

He is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase additional load to sell for his electronic re-loading business.

Nilo has been in this business for one year. Nilo earns more income from food vending.

Nilo has been sustaining his business activities through his own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. He dreams to save money to expand his business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional load credits to sell

loans.name: Marelyn

texts.en:
Marelyn is 44 years old, married, and has three children. She is currently residing in Polangyuta, Siquijor in Siquijor, in the Philippines.

She has been engaged in this business for almost nine years to earn a living. She gets a monthly net income of 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from this retail business.

She has been a member of PMPC for less than a year and has requested a loan amounting to 9,000 PHP to purchase more products for retailing and further expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of gasoline to sell

loans.name: Eutiquia

texts.en:
Eutiquia is a 43-year-old married woman and a mother of four children from Nocnocan, Talibon. She has been engaged in a rice farming business with her family for almost 15 years now. Her husband works as fish pond keeper in their place.

Eutiquia is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm. With this, they will be able to produce a good quality of harvest, thus allowing them to sell more to the market.

In the future, Eutiquia hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for the farm

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion is 55 years old and lives in New Dapitan. She is married with three children.

Visitacion has a retail business and earns approximately PHP 8,700 each month doing this type of work. She has a requested a loan to purchase additional inventory for her grocery store. 

Visitacion has been a member of PMPC for 2 years.

loans.use: To purchase additional store inventory

location.town: Calamba-New Dapitan, Rizal, Zambo. Del Norte

loans.name: Dagvadorj

texts.en:
Dagvadorj is a 65-year-old widower who lives alone in a ger in Arkhangai Province, Mongolia. His wife passed away a year ago and his children are all  married and live away from him. Dagvadorj has been operating his transportation business since 2003. Unfortunately, his truck has broken down and needs some repairs so he can provide transportation services. He is now working as a security guard at a local shopping center. 

Dagvadorj is requesting a loan of 400,000 MNT to fix his truck and restart his transportation business. He is a well-behaved, hard-working person.

loans.use: to fix his truck and restart his transportation business

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Sharon works hard to support her family.  She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming rice and raising pigs. Sharon is borrowing PHP 23,000 through NWTF to buy additional items to sell such as shampoo, toothpaste, coffee, canned goods, etc. for her general store business.

Sharon has been sustaining her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell such as shampoo, toothpaste, coffee, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Erdenebayar

texts.en: Mr. Erdenebayar is 22-years-old and lives with his wife and son in a ger in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. His wife, Saihanchimeg aged 25 years, works as a saleswoman in the local market. His son, Dolgoon aged 2 years, goes to kindergarten. He has been working at a printing company since he graduated from secondary school. He has gained experience from his printing job and now he is starting his own business of computers, editing, and printing services in the local market where people need this service very often. He is requesting 1,500,000 MNT to purchase a color printer and various types of paper to run his business smoothly from the beginning. He is sharp, friendly, and a hardworking person.

loans.use: to purchase a color printer and various types of paper to run his business smoothly from the beginning.

loans.name: Vesitacion

texts.en: Vesitacion works hard to support her family. She is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business, which she has had for eight years now.  In the future, Vesitacion would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Erelhegmongol

texts.en: Mr. Erelhegmongol is 25 years old lives with his mother in a small house in Songinohairhan district of Mongolia. His mother helps him to restart his father's public transportation service. His father used to be a public transportation driver. He passed away a year ago. He has inherited his father's old car that is broken, and he is not be able to provide transportation business with it. So, he is now requesting MNT 3,900,000 to purchase a better second-hand car to provide transportation service to local customers. He is an honest and diligent person.

loans.use: to purchase a better second-hand car to provide transportation service to local customers.

loans.name: Annalisa

texts.en:
Annalisa  previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more grocery items and products for her business. Her earnings were a big help in paying for her child’s education and their personal, household and business expenditure. 

Annalisa would like to apply for another loan of  40,000 PHP to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed in the store the better as more items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her child’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Annalisa hopes her business will grow in the coming years and she dreams of giving her family a good future through her hard work. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups of 15 to 30 that meet weekly. The groups study the Word of God, build social capital, and encourage the repayment of micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages to sell

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa is 68 years old and lives in Dolipos Alto, Oroquieta City, Philippines. She is married with 10 children. Luisa is a farmer and has been growing coconuts to earn a living for the past  20 years.

Luisa has requested a loan of  14,900 PHP to redeem her pawned coconut farmland. She has been a member of PMPC for three years. Luisa hopes to have a brighter future ahead.

loans.use: to redeem her pawned coconut farmland

loans.name: Sawe Mutiara Indah Group

texts.en:
The Sawe Mutiara Indah group will receive their new loan with each member receiving the same loan amount. The loan continues to be for expanding their pig businesses. Besides purchasing piglets, members will also use the loan to renovate their barns and buy feed.

Ayu Ketut will use her loan to purchase three superior piglets for fattening which she will sell five months later. Income for their daily needs comes from her shop business, and her husband is really happy with that. He supports his wife’s pig-raising business by feeding the pigs and washing out the barn every afternoon. Ayu Ketut and her husband hope that both of the businesses, the pig-raising and the shop, will succeed.

loans.use: to purchase three superior piglets

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase cloth and beads for embroidery work.

loans.name: Denisse

texts.es:
Denisse, de 29 años es una mujer admirable. Vive en compañía de sus padres y hermanos en su casa propia.  
Desde joven comenzó a afrontar el negocio de su familia, reparte su tiempo en la venta de queso y sus estudios de Administración de empresas en una universidad reconocida de la ciudad.  En la altura del pueblo de Yauyos, tiene una granja, donde cuida de sus 100 vacas, de las cuales sus padres elaboran queso que ella trae para comercializarlos de acuerdo al peso de los moldes. Cuenta que tiene pedidos de las diferentes ciudades cercanas, que son conocedores de su buena producción. Para cuidar de la calidad ella viaja 2 veces al mes, pues también crían ovejas de las cuales comercializa su carne, “hay meses, donde los pedidos sobrepasan mi producción, para abastecer tengo que comprar a otros ganaderos”, cuenta. Ahora tiene muchos pedidos y espera poder abastecer a sus clientes, pues su objetivo es industrializar su queso. Ella pertenece al grupo solidario “San Lorenzo” y este es el segundo crédito con MFP, por tanto espera de un pequeño préstamo para que pueda cumplir con sus objetivos. Por otro lado promete cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas, como en anterior crédito que tuvo. Además le agrada ser parte de su asociación porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y solidarias.
Denisse de recibir su apoyo; invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de varios moldes de queso para su negocio.
texts.en:
Denisse, 29, is an admirable woman. She lives together with her parents and siblings in their own house. Since she was young, she took responsibility for her family’s business. She distributes her time between selling cheese and studying business administration in an accredited university in the city. In the town of Yauyos, she has a farm where she takes care of 100 cows. Her parents make the cheese from their milk and she sells it according to the molds’ weight.

She receives orders from various neighboring cities, where people know about the good quality of the farm's products. In order to assure the product’s quality she travels two times a month. The family also raises sheep and sells their meat. "Some months, orders outrun my production, so I have to buy from other farmers in order to stock my business", she says. She has now many orders and expects to be able to serve them, since her objective is to industrialize her production of cheese.

Denisse is a member of the "San Lorenzo" group and this is the second credit with MFP, so she expects to get a small loan in order to meet her goals. On the other hand she promises to pay the installments in time, just as she did with the previous loan. She enjoys being a part of the association because all its members are responsible persons and work together as a team.

In case she gets this loan, she will invest it in cheese molds for her business.

loans.use: to buy cheese molds.

loans.name: Darisuren

texts.en:
Darisuren is a 57-year-old widow who lives with her mother and her son in a house in Arkhangai Province, Mongolia. Her mother is a pensioner and requires constant care. Her son, Lhagvasuren, aged 22, studies at university and helps her to take care of her mother. 

Darisuren has been working as a tailor in a private tailoring company for over 10 years and has gained a lot of experience. She has been tailoring some of her relatives' clothes in her free time. Now Darisuren is planning to establish her tailoring business in her spare room as she needs to stay near her mother. She is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to purchase a new sewing machine and inventory for her business. She is a diligent, hard-working and responsible woman

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine and inventory for her new tailoring business

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is 57 years old and lives in Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with two children. Alicia has a store where she sells groceries and other consumable products. She has had this business for almost 20 years. 

Alicia has requested a loan to be used for purchasing additional groceries to sell. She has been a member of PMPC for almost four years.  In the future, Alicia hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional groceries to sell

loans.name: Rona Joy

texts.en:
Rona Joy is 28 years old and is married with three children who are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Rona Joy has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She has requested a 29,500 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks like canned goods, sugar, milk, coffee, etc. to sell. Rona Joy has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stock like canned goods, sugar, milk, coffee, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Gbenonkpo Group

texts.fr: GBENONKPO est un groupe de six personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Edwige, âgée de 47 ans, est mariée à Césaire, un menuisier. Edwige a un peu fréquenté. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Edwige et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Il y a près de dix neuf ans que Edwige vend des volailles et des noix de palme dans un marché du Bénin. Edwige exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Edwige s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Edwige sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe GBENONKPO, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits. Les crédits antérieurement reçus ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The "Gbenonkpo" group comprises six people who all live in the same area. The group leader, Edwige, is 47 years old and married to Césaire, a carpenter. Edwige has a little bit of schooling. The couple have five children, all in school and in the care of their parents. Edwige and her husband live together with their children and provide for the household together. For close to ten years, Edwige has sold poultry and palm nuts at a market in Benin. She runs this business with passion, which has allowed her to provide for her needs and those of her children. Edwige gets her supplies at a market in Benin. With the goal of satisfying her clientele, Edwige is seeking a third loan with ALIDÉ, together with the other members of the Gbenonkpo group. This loan will serve to better respond to the needs of their customers and generate higher profits. All the previous loans were repaid properly.

loans.use: To buy chickens and palm nuts.

loans.name: Antonietta

texts.en:
Antonietta is 41 years old and married with two children who are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Antonietta has had a business making and selling dried fish in the Philippines for 14 years. 

She has requested a 20,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase additional fish for her business.

In the future, Antonietta would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish for her business.
